title: K-set (geometry)
summary: In discrete geometry, a k {\displaystyle k} -set of a finite point set S {\displaystyle S} in the Euclidean plane is a subset of k {\displaystyle k} elements of S {\displaystyle S} that can be strictly separated from the remaining points by a line. More generally, in Euclidean space of higher dimensions, a k {\displaystyle k} -set of a finite point set is a subset of k {\displaystyle k} elements that can be separated from the remaining points by a hyperplane. In particular, when k = n / 2 {\displaystyle k=n/2} (where n {\displaystyle n} is the size of S {\displaystyle S} ), the line or hyperplane that separates a k {\displaystyle k} -set from the rest of S {\displaystyle S} is a halving line or halving plane.
